label.text: In 2020, NASA sent a six-wheeled robot (rover) called Perseverance to Mars. Perseverance was designed to seek signs of ancient life and to collect rock samples.

A spacecraft carried Perseverance to Mars. A parachute was used to slow down the spacecraft as it approached the planet. The video represents how a rocket-fired vehicle was then deployed, which lowered Perseverance to the surface of Mars. The video has no sound.
After Perseverance landed, it began sending images and videos back to Earth using radio waves.
Radio waves travel at the speed of light and yet it takes people on Earth almost 14 minutes to receive images from Perseverance.
Why does it take so long to receive images from Perseverance?
The cameras work slowly on Mars.
The distance between Earth and Mars is enormous.
The speed of the radio waves is significantly reduced when the radio waves enter Earthâ€™s atmosphere.
Radio waves do not travel quickly in the vacuum of space.
